Dear Mack McGhee:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a corrective action plan is required. The corrective action
plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter, must be completed and routed in CWLM,
and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Claudia Triestram at 616-552-3662.

Sincerely,
Dayna Lamkey, MA, LLPC
Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & R 400.4109 Program statement.
Section Rule 109. (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written
Description program statement which specifically addresses all of the
following: (c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission,
care, safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’
needs, implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of
residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A was forced to horseplay by two other youth. Staff were
not intervening.
Investigation Complainant contacts were attempted on 4/29/25, 5/6/25, and
5/29/25 with no response.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on 5/1/25
along with MDHHS Specialist. Youth A reported he remembered
the incident when he broke the window on pod 2D after being
upset. Youth A reported he was upset because Youth B kept
playing too much and would not stop. Youth A reported Youth B
kept hitting and smacking him. Youth A reported Staff 3 asked him
to stop but he kept doing it. Youth A reported Staff 2 was also
there but did not do anything. Youth A did not remember what
other staff were present or what other youth were present.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on 5/1/25
along with MDHHS Specialist. Youth B reported Youth A is like a
little brother to him who he always plays around with. Youth B
reported that before Youth A broke the window on the pod that
Youth B and Youth C were playing around with Youth A before it
happened. Youth B reported Youth A got mad and took their
playing with him the wrong way. Youth B described playing around
with Youth A as horseplaying. Youth B reported at first Youth A
was playing too by poking back at Youth B and Youth C until
Youth A hit his own foot or something and got mad. Youth B
reported staff in the area were watching the entire time. Youth B
identified staff present as Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3. Youth B
reported a staff told them to stop at one point which they did and
then they started to play around again soon after. Youth B did not
recall which staff instructed them to stop.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at the facility on 5/1/25
along with MDHHS Specialist. Youth C reported he was present
for the incident in which Youth A broke the window and did not
2

recall what staff or other youth were involved. Youth C reported
Youth A broke the window after getting mad that he was being
picked on. Youth C reported the other youth were play smacking
with Youth A who was playing back for a time. Youth C denied
recollecting what staff did or if they intervened at any point.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 5/1/25 along
with MDHHS Specialist. Staff 1 reported prior to Youth A breaking
the window, Youth B was playing around with Youth A. Staff 1
reported she told them to stop but they continued until Youth A got
mad and broke the window. Staff 1 reported Youth A was not
upset while the playing was going on and that he was participating
with them. Staff 1 reported they were putting hands on each other.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 5/1/25 along
with MDHHS Specialist. Staff 2 reported she was on the pod for
rounds and observed Youth A and Youth B horseplaying. Staff 2
reported giving Staff 3 a minute to intervene and she did not. Staff
2 reported advising Staff 3 that she needed to intervene. Staff 2
reported that Youth A and Youth B were playing but it was clear
that Youth A wanted to stop when Youth A told Youth B to stop.
Staff 2 reported she and Staff 1 then intervened and Staff 3 called
for a supervisor due to smacking escalating between Youth A and
Youth B. Staff 2 reported Youth B stopped and Youth A started to
pace around angry and went to the window and broke it.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 5/1/25 along
with MDHHS Specialist. Staff 3 reported Youth A and Youth B
were horse playing as they always do, stating that they play like
brothers. Staff 3 reported at one point Youth A wanted to be by
himself when Youth B continued to try to play around with him
which made Youth A mad. Staff 3 reported it was then that Youth
A broke the window. Staff 3 denied that Youth A complained about
being bullied or harassed. Staff 3 reported she redirected Youth B
multiple times to stop horseplaying with Youth A.
Documents Reviewed:
• Resident Orientation Booklet states that horseplay
between other youth and with staff is prohibited.
• Incident report dated 4/24/25 states that Youth B
and Youth C were engaging in horseplay, slapping
Youth A. IR states that staff redirected verbally
multiple times and that the horseplaying stopped
and then began again. IR states that Youth A
became aggressive and started kicking the glass on
the classroom door.
3

• Discipline records for Staff 3 documents 1
suspension for failure to alert supervision of an
incident occurring.
• Discipline records for Staff 2 documents 1
suspension related to attendance.
• Training record for Staff 1 documents 77.5 hours of
training in 2025 including Handle with Care Verbal
Physical Intervention and Red Flags and
Boundaries.
• Training record for Staff 2 documents 41 hours of
training in 2024 and 2 in 2025 including Handle with
Care Verbal/Physical Refresher and Verbal/Physical
Intervention,
• Training record for Staff 3 documents 241 hours of
training in 2024 9.5 hours of training in 2025
including Handle with Care refresher, and Handle
with Care Verbal/Physical Intervention.
Video Reviewed:
• Video footage of pod 2D on 4/24/25 at
approximately 8:16 PM was reviewed on 5/8/25.
• Video footage shows at 8:17 PM Staff 1 can be
seen pushing Youth B in a horseplaying manner. At
8:18 PM Youth B and Youth C begin horseplaying
with Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3 shadowboxing
movements. 6 minutes into video Youth A
approaches and Youth B and Youth C transition
from horseplay with staff to attempt to horseplay
with Youth A by poking and smacking Youth A with
their hands. Youth A gets up and runs to the other
end of the pod and lays down as Youth B and Youth
C kick and smack him. In the video Staff 1, Staff 2,
and Staff 3 are nearby talking to one another. Youth
A gets up and is seen yelling and walking away at
which time he goes around the wall where there is
no video footage and he breaks the window.
Analysis A rule violation is established regarding this allegation. It was
reported by all youth and staff that Youth B and Youth C engaged
in horseplay with Youth A which is against facility policy. Although
it was reported verbal direction was attempted, it was also
reported by staff that it continued with no additional redirection or
response form staff. Further, Staff 1 and Staff 2 are seen in video
footage engaging in the horseplay with Youth B and Youth C,
when Youth A is seen entering the area, Youth B and Youth C
turn their attention to Youth A who then escalates.
4

Conclusion Repeat Violation Established

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
